awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: An integrated mantle to surface study of the causes and consequences of high topography in the Northern US Cordillera
awd_abstract_narration:
Recent theoretical advances suggest processes occurring deep within Earth's mantle can have significant impacts on topography at Earth's surface. As topographic history of a region can influence the climate and biologic evolution, understanding the role of the mantle in shaping the landscape is paramount to understanding the Earth as a system. A major barrier to the study of mantle and surface process linkages is that few locations exist where time histories of past mantle and surface events can be well constrained. The inland northwest, which includes the well-studied passage of the Yellowstone hotspot, offers a unique opportunity to examine the role mantle dynamics play in mountain uplift and landscape evolution. This project, which focuses on field sites in Oregon and Idaho, is designed as an integrated mantle to surface study that quantifies the regional erosion history and the structure of the upper mantle beneath this region.  Results from this work will motivate generalized models incorporating different mantle processes and the topographic response to a range in uplift patterns. As a result, our findings, while specific to our field sites, may help shed light on mantle and surface interactions around the globe. The project will support three graduate students and three Primary Investigators from separate collaborating research institutions. The project also unites academic scientists and research students with public educators and science communicators through a partnership with two eastern Oregon organizations: Wallowa Resources, an organization that engages in educational outreach, environmental action, and renewable energy programs and Wallowology, the only natural history museum in this region.


The role of mantle dynamics in driving uplift and landscape evolution is a critical and poorly understood facet of geodynamics and geomorphology research. This project will explore mantle driven epeiorogenic uplift and landscape evolution north of the Yellowstone plume track in the rugged and mountainous Inland Northwest of the United States. Nowhere else has a continent experienced such a recent and profound interaction with a mantle plume, making this area the ideal candidate for the examination of lithosphere-scale responses to mantle dynamics. Guiding our investigation are four testable hypotheses of lithospheric and landscape responses to the Yellowstone plume: (1) uplift and erosion following lithospheric loss through delamination, (2) uplift and erosion following lithospheric loss through drip-like Rayleigh-Taylor convection, (3) uplift and erosion following flattening of the buoyant Yellowstone plume, and (4) erosion driven by faulting induced drainage reorganization. We will build on a strong foundation of prior seismic, geologic and landscape studies across northeastern Oregon and central Idaho. This targeted study will resolve regional landscape evolution and its relation to imaged mantle structure via the integration of geologic and geomorphic field observations, low-temperature thermochronology, and detrital cosmogenic radionuclide derived erosion rates and mantle tomography through geodynamic and landscape evolution modeling. The research will generate models that relate mantle dynamics to uplift and landscape development, constrained by data from our study area and applicable to other locations throughout earth history. This work will help to refine plate-tectonics theory by providing a robust study of intraplate deformation not related to plate boundary forces. Furthermore, we anticipate this study will give the clearest-yet measure of the importance of sub-crustal mantle deformation on landscape evolution, a critical topic in studies from the Andes to Tibet.

por.por_cntn:
Most mountains and zones of active erosion on Earth relate to a plate tectonic boundary where plates are either colliding or pulling apart from one another. Away from these boundaries, a less common and cryptic source of mountain building relates to activity in the Earth's Mantle, far beneath the surface where humans reside. The role of the mantle in building mountains and driving erosion of the landscape is a poorly understood facet of geology research, primarily because it is more difficult to study, especially events that happened far back in geologic time. In this project, our research advanced understanding of this subject by studying Earth's surface response to the millions of years passage of the mobile Yellowstone volcanic plume track in the rugged and mountainous Inland Northwest of the United States. 

The Salmon River watershed of Idaho shows classic features of a geologically "young" landscape in flux, including a greater than one kilometer deep canyon carves through perched surfaces of low relief. The cause of this canyon formation is still debated. The nearby Wallowa Mountains of northeastern Oregon too have baffled researchers, as they have much higher relief than the surrounding landscape, but are situated far away from a tectonic plate boundary, at least presently. Other geological studies of the Wallowa Mountains have hypothesized a connection between the mountains and Yellowstone volcanic chain, which owes its formation to a "hotspot" in the mantle, initiating in this region ~17 million years ago. Modeling of the Salmon river also suggests a possible connection to Yellowstone. Previous studies suggest that this canyon formed in response to regional mountain building ~8-10 million years ago during the same geologic time window that the Yellowstone volcanic chain moved west through the Idaho region.

In order to test these ideas, researchers on this project used a combination of geologic dating methods, geologic and geomorphic mapping, geophysical techniques and modeling to resolve the timing and drivers of mountain uplift, erosion, and river canyon formation. Results from our project do support that the high-elevation mountains and fast-eroding rivers of northeastern Oregon and central Idaho correlate with mantle processes interpreted from seismic data. However, our work also revealed the surprising result that, despite the geologically youthfull appearance of the mountains and landscape, both the Wallowa Mountains and the Salmon River canyon had already formed, at least partially, over 20 million years earlier than the coupled mantle to surface response to the Yellowstone volcanic plume.

Beyond determining the geology and landscape history of this particular region, our studies provide insight and methods approach applicable to other geologic settings and general understandings of plate tectonics. Specifically, this work provides a robust study of mountain and river canyon formation not related to regions far away from tectonic plate boundaries, where we expect these features to be and where we can explain them by plate tectonic forces and theory. Indeed, our work demonstrates the importance of deep mantle to Earth surface connections, a critical topic in studies relevant to similar mountain belts around the world and plate tectonic settings around the world.

The research team engaged together in research, teaching, and training as part of this work. The project supported several University of Washington undergraduates and graduate students and a junior professor at the time of funding.  During the course of the project, PI Duvall was promoted from Assistant to Associate Professor, and two graduate students, Philip Schoetttle-Greene and Seth Williams earned a PhD and MS degree respectively. The team collaborated closely with researchers on the project at University of Oregon and Indiana University, broadening the network of all involved. The team communicated research findings from the project at international geology conferences, in research publications, and to the public through science outreach programs such as the University of Washington's "Rockin Out" and the Wallowology Natural History Discovery Center in Oregon.
